“Forkmeiamfamous”: Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory 
Low-profile information-stealing Trojan is used only against high-value targets.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
By: Symantec Security Response
Symantec Employee



Created 13 Jul 2015 
0
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
Comments

: 
日本語


Bookmark






Google+0

Twitter


submit


Email















Symantec has uncovered an elusive Trojan used by the cyberespionage group behind the “Duke” family of malware.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Seaduke (detected by Symantec as Trojan.Seaduke) is a low-profile information-stealing Trojan which appears to be reserved for attacks against a small number of high-value targets.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Seaduke has been used in attacks against a number of major, government-level targets.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: The malware hides behind numerous layers of encryption and obfuscation and is capable of quietly stealing and exfiltrating sensitive information such as email from the victim’s computer.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Seaduke has a highly configurable framework and Symantec has already found hundreds of different configurations on compromised networks.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Its creators are likely to have spent a considerable amount of time and resources in preparing these attacks and the malware has been deployed against a number of high-level government targets.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: While the Duke group began to distribute Cozyduke in an increasingly aggressive manner, Seaduke installations were reserved only for select targets.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Seaduke victims are generally first infected with Cozyduke and, if the computer appears to be a target of interest, the operators will install Seaduke.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
Background
	The group behind Seaduke is a cyberespionage operation that is responsible for a series of attacks against high-profile individuals and organizations in government, international policy and private research in the United States and Europe.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: It has a range of malware tools at its disposal, known as the Dukes, including Cozyduke (Trojan.Cozer), Miniduke (Backdoor.Miniduke) and Cosmicduke (Backdoor.Tinybaron).
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: News of the Duke group first emerged in  March and April of 2015, when reports detailing attacks involving a sophisticated threat actor variously called Office Monkeys, EuroAPT, Cozy Bear, and Cozyduke were published.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Symantec believes that this group has a history of compromising governmental and diplomatic organizations since at least 2010.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: The group began its current campaign as early as March 2014, when Trojan.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Cozer (aka Cozyduke) was identified on the network of a private research institute in Washington, D.C.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: In the months that followed, the Duke group began to target victims with “Office Monkeys”- and “eFax”-themed emails, booby-trapped with a Cozyduke payload.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: These tactics were atypical of a cyberespionage group.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: It’s quite likely these themes were deliberately chosen to act as a smokescreen, hiding the true intent of the adversary.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Figure 1.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
Cozyduke campaign used an “Office Monkeys” video as a lure–July 2014
The Duke group has mounted an extended campaign targeting high-profile networks over extended periods, something which is far beyond the reach of the majority of threat actors.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
Its capabilities include:

Attack infrastructure leveraging hundreds of compromised websites
Rapidly developed malware frameworks in concurrent use
Sophisticated operators with fine-tuned computer network exploitation (CNE) skills

Although Cozyduke activity was first identified in March 2014, it wasn’t until July that the group managed to successfully compromise high-profile government networks.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Cozyduke was used throughout these attacks to harvest and exfiltrate sensitive information to the attackers.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: In parallel, the Duke group was also installing separate malware onto these networks, namely Backdoor.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Miniduke and the more elusive Trojan.Seaduke.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: It could use these payloads to exploit networks on multiple fronts and providing it with additional persistence mechanisms.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
The Miniduke payload
	In July of 2014, the group instructed Cozyduke-infected computers to install Backdoor.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Miniduke onto a compromised network.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Miniduke has been the group’s tool of choice for a number of years in espionage operations predominantly targeting government and diplomatic entities in Eastern Europe and ex-Soviet states.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: “Nemesis Gemina” appears to be the internal name for the framework used by the group to identify the project, previously reported by Kaspersky.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
The following debug string was present in the sample used in these attacks:

C:\Projects\nemesis-gemina\nemesis\bin\carriers\ezlzma_x86_exe.pdb

This project name has been seen in Backdoor.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Tinybaron (aka Cosmicduke) samples, which Symantec also attributes to the Duke group.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: This deployment of Miniduke and the technical similarities with Cozyduke provided strong indicators as to who was behind the attacks.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
The Seaduke payload
	These attacks were already well underway when another group began to deploy a previously unknown piece of malware.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: In October 2014, the Seaduke payload began to appear within target networks.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Although Seaduke was developed in Python, the overall framework bears a striking resemblance to Cozyduke in terms of operation.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: It’s unclear why the attackers waited until October to deploy Seaduke.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Was it reserved for a more specific attack?
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Was part of their cover blown, necessitating the use of an alternative framework?
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: The Seaduke framework was designed to be highly configurable.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Hundreds of reconfigurations were identified on compromised networks.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: The communication protocol employed had many layers of encryption and obfuscation, using over 200 compromised web servers for command and control.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Seaduke required a significant investment of time and resources in the preparatory and operational phases of the attack.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
Seaduke delivery
	The attackers control Cozyduke via compromised websites, issuing instructions to infected machines by uploading “tasks” to a database file.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Cozyduke will periodically contact these websites to retrieve task information to be executed on the local machine.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
One such task (an encoded PowerShell script) instructed Cozyduke to download and execute Seaduke from a compromised website. 

Figure 2.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
How the attacker tasks Cozer to install Seaduke
Seaduke operation
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: The attackers can operate Seaduke in a broadly similar fashion to Cozyduke.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: The Seaduke control infrastructure is essentially distinct, opening up the possibility of sub-teams concurrently exploiting the target network.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Unlike Cozyduke, Seaduke operators upload “task” files directly to the command-and-control (C&C) server; there is no database as such present.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Seaduke securely communicates with the C&C server over HTTP/HTTPS beneath layers of encoding (Base64) and encryption (RC4, AES).
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: To an untrained eye, the communications look fairly benign, no doubt an effort to stay under the radar on compromised networks.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Figure 3.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
How Seaduke operates on the target network
Seaduke has many inbuilt commands which are available to the attackers.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: They have the ability to retrieve detailed bot/system information, update bot configuration, upload files, download files, and self-delete the malware from the system.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: The self-delete function is interestingly called “seppuku”.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: This is a form of Japanese ritual suicide.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
Seaduke payloads
	The attackers have also developed a number of additional payloads.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Operators can push these payloads onto infected machines for very specific attacks.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Impersonation using Kerberos pass-the-ticket attacks (Mimikatz PowerShell)
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text:
Email extraction from the MS Exchange Server using compromised credentials
Archiving sensitive information
Data exfiltration via legitimate cloud services
Secure file deletion
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: What next?
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: The Duke group has brought its operational capability to the next level.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Its attacks have been so bold and aggressive, that a huge amount of attention has been drawn to it, yet it appears to be unperturbed.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Its success at compromising such high-profile targets has no doubt added a few feathers to its cap.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Even the developers reveled in this fact, naming one of Seaduke’s functions “forkmeiamfamous”.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: While the group is currently keeping a lower profile, there’s no doubt it will reappear.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: Some tools may have to be abandoned, some reworked and others built completely from scratch.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

text: This attack group is in it for the long haul.
source: “Forkmeiamfamous”_ Seaduke, latest weapon in the Duke armory _ Symantec Connect Community.html

CrowdStrike’s work with the Democratic National Committee:
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
Setting the record straight

June 5, 2020 Editorial Team From The Front Lines 


June 5, 2020 UPDATE
Blog update following the release of the testimony by Shawn Henry, CSO and President of CrowdStrike Services, before the House Intelligence Committee that was recently declassified.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: What was CrowdStrike’s role in investigating the hack of the DNC?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike was contacted on April 30, 2016 to respond to a suspected breach.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We began our work with the DNC on May 1, 2016, collecting intelligence and analyzing the breach.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: After conducting this analysis and identifying the adversaries on the network, on June 10, 2016 we initiated a coordinated remediation event to ensure the intruders were removed and could not regain access.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: That remediation process lasted approximately 2-3 days and was completed on June 13, 2016.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Why did the DNC contact CrowdStrike?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The DNC contacted CrowdStrike to respond to a suspected cyber attack impacting its network.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The DNC was first alerted to the hack by the FBI in September 2015.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: According to testimony by DNC IT contractor Yared Tamene Wolde-Yohannes, the FBI attributed the breach to the Russian Government in September 2015 (page 7).
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Why did the DNC hire CrowdStrike instead of just working with the FBI to investigate the hack?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The FBI doesn’t perform incident response or network remediation services when organizations need to get back to business after a breach.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike is a leader in protecting customers around the world from cyber threats.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: It is common for organizations to hire third-party industry experts, like CrowdStrike, to investigate and remediate cyber attacks when they suspect a breach even if they are collaborating with law enforcement.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
As John Carlin, former Assistant Attorney General for the National Security Division at The Department of Justice, testified before the House Intelligence Committee (cited from page 21 of his testimony):
“A lot of — outside of any political organization, companies, most corporations, they often would use these third party contractors, who they hired through their own counsel, and maximize the control from the point of view of the victim.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Did CrowdStrike have proof that Russia hacked the DNC?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Yes, and this is also supported by the U.S. Intelligence community and independent Congressional reports.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Following a comprehensive investigation that CrowdStrike detailed publicly, the company concluded in May 2016 that two separate Russian intelligence-affiliated adversaries breached the DNC network.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: To reference, CrowdStrike’s account of their DNC investigation, published on June 14, 2016, “CrowdStrike Services Inc., our Incident Response group, was called by the Democratic National Committee (DNC), the formal governing body for the US Democratic Party, to respond to a suspected breach.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We deployed our IR team and technology and immediately identified two sophisticated adversaries on the network – COZY BEAR and FANCY BEAR….
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: At DNC, COZY BEAR intrusion has been identified going back to summer of 2015, while FANCY BEAR separately breached the network in April 2016.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This conclusion has most recently been supported by the Senate Intelligence Committee in April 2020 issuing a report
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: [intelligence.senate.gov] validating the previous conclusions of the Intelligence community, published on January 6, 2017,  that Russia was behind the DNC data breach.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
The Senate report states on page 48:
“The Committee found that specific intelligence as well as open source assessments support the assessment that President Putin approved and directed aspects of this influence campaign.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
Furthermore, in his testimony in front of the House Intelligence Committee, Shawn Henry stated the following with regards to CrowdStrike’s degree of confidence that the intrusion activity can be attributed to Russia, cited from page 24:

 HENRY: We said that we had a high degree of confidence it was the Russian Government.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: And our analysts that looked at it and that had looked at these types of attacks before, many different types of attacks similar to this in different environments, certain tools that were used, certain methods by which they were moving in the environment,and looking at the types of data that was being targeted, that it was consistent with a nation-state adversary and associated with Russian intelligence.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Have any other organizations concluded that Russia was behind the DNC hack?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Yes.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike’s conclusion that Russia was behind the DNC hack is supported by the U.S. Intelligence community and also by independent Congressional reports.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Most recently, the Senate Intelligence Committee released a report in April 2020 that validated the previous conclusions of the Intelligence Community Assessment, published on January 6, 2017, all concluding that Russia was behind the DNC data breach.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Page 157 of the Senate report states that the Select Committee on Intelligence “conducted an extensive examination of the intelligence demonstrating Russia’s intrusions into DNC networks.“
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Senator Richard Burr (R – North Carolina), who served as Chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee at the time the report was issued, confirmed this finding: “The Committee found no reason to dispute the Intelligence Community’s conclusions.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The Intelligence Community Assessment, published on January 6, 2017 also confirms that Russia was behind the DNC hack, stating on page 2 of the report: “In July 2015, Russian intelligence gained access to Democratic National Committee (DNC) networks and maintained that access until at least June 2016.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This unclassified ODNI report was based on extensive classified intelligence collected by the CIA, NSA, and FBI; the ODNI determined the classified intelligence should not be released in order to protect the sensitive sources and methods by which it was collected.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: It’s also worth noting that other security companies, including Fidelis and FireEye have supported CrowdStrike’s analysis.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Does CrowdStrike have evidence that data was exfiltrated from the DNC network?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Yes.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Shawn Henry stated in his testimony to the House Intelligence Committee that CrowdStrike had indicators of exfiltration (page 32)  and that data had clearly left the network.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Also, on page 2, the Intelligence Community Assessment also confirmed that the Russian intelligence agency GRU “had exfiltrated large volumes of data from the DNC.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Did CrowdStrike see in real-time the adversaries exfiltrate data and emails from the DNC network?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: No and that’s typical for incident response cases.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: In the vast majority of cyber investigations, incident responders don’t witness exfiltration in real-time.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: In fact, often we are called in after theft has taken place.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We collect forensics, evidence of prior activity on the network, map where the adversary has gained access and prepare remediation plans.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: In this particular case, CrowdStrike saw circumstantial evidence of data exfiltration from the DNC network.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: As a reference point circumstantial evidence is the type of evidence such as DNA analysis or fingerprints that are fully admissible in courts.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
Shawn Henry stated in his testimony that CrowdStrike had indicators of exfiltration (page 32 of the testimony):
“Counsel just reminded me that, as it relates to the DNC’ we have indicators that data was exfiltrated.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
We did not have concrete evidence that data was exfiltrated from the DNC, but we have indicators that it was exfiltrated.’
and circumstantial evidence that data was taken as he states on page 75 ”so there is circumstantial evidence that it was taken” and page 76:
“MR.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: HENRY:
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: So, to go back, because I think it’s important to characterize this.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We didn’t have a network sensor in place that saw data leave’
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We said that the data Ieft based on the circumstantial evidence.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: That was a conclusion that we made.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: when I answered that question, I was trying to be as factually accurate’ I want to provide the facts.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: so I said that we didn’t have direct evidence’
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: But we made a conclusion that the data left the network.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
On page 32 of the testimony, Henry also explains that
“We don’t have video of it happening, but there are indicators that it happened” and “we did not have concrete evidence that data was exfiltrated from the DNC, but we have indicators that it was exfiltrated.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
As another reference point, the independent report by Special Counsel Robert S. Mueller also cites the theft of documents from the DNC and DCCC on page 40, stating the following:
“Officers from Unit 26165 stole thousands of documents from the DCCC and DNC networks, including significant amounts of data pertaining to the 2016 U.S. federal elections.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Stolen documents included internal strategy documents, fundraising data, opposition research, and emails from the work inboxes of DNC employees.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Is it true that part of the exfiltration happened after CrowdStrike was already engaged by the DNC?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This question about the specific timeline of the exfiltration is addressed directly by Shawn Henry in his testimony on page 26.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: “MR.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: HENRY:
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: So the analysis started the first day or two in May, and then that was about 4 to 6 weeks.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: I think, on June 10th, we started what we call the remediation event.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: so we collected enough intelligence.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We identified where the adversaries were in the environment’ We came up with a remediation plan to say we see them in multiple locations.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This – these are the actions that we need to execute in order to put a new infrastructure in place and to ensure that the adversaries don’t have access to the new infrastructure.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: So that would have been June 10th when we started.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: And we did the remediation event over a couple of days.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Of note, it is a standard practice in incident response to first coordinate a remediation event to prevent the adversary from doing further damage and following that to fully restore network functionality.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We followed industry best practices to accomplish the fastest remediation path for our customer.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
On page 27 of Shawn Henry’s testimony, he further explains CrowdStrike’s role as incident responders:
“To be clear, our goal, my goal was to protect the client.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We were hired to protect the client.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We identified an adversary there.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The goal was to make sure that the adversary was removed and the client had a clean environment with which to work.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Did any DNC endpoints protected by your technology get breached in subsequent attacks?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: There is no indication of subsequent breaches taking place on any DNC machine protected by CrowdStrike Falcon®.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Do you have a comment about the allegation that Russia stole Democratic Party emails from John Podesta and then passed them to WikiLeaks?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike was not involved in investigating John Podesta’s email leaks.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Henry says on page 62 of this testimony, he “has no relationship with them [the Podesta emails].”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: What is the timeline of the DNC hack?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: According to public records, this is the timeline of the DNC hack that CrowdStrike was hired to investigate.  :
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Beginning in July 2015:  “Russian intelligence gained access to Democratic National Committee (DNC) networks ( page 2).
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Sept. 25, 2015:  An FBI agent contacted the DNC Information Technology director/contractor in charge of the DNC network, alerting him to suspicious activity in the network and referencing the “Dukes” (p16), a well-known pseudonym in the cybersecurity community for Russian government actors.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
The FBI agent called the DNC again in October 2015, November 2015, December 2015 (p12) asking the contractor to “corroborate, to look into specific activities that the FBI had noticed emanating from the DNC network that could be nefarious.”  (p8)
Beginning in December 2015: Russian intelligence actors engaged in attacks on election systems, including scanning a “widely used vendor of election systems,” according to DHS.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The  attacks continued through June 2016 (p30.)
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Beginning April 2016:
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The GRU  “…stole thousands of documents from the DCCC and DNC networks, including significant amounts of data pertaining to the 2016 U.S. federal elections.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Stolen documents included internal strategy documents, fundraising data, opposition research, and emails from the work inboxes of DNC employees.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html
Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: “The GRU began stealing DCCC data shortly after it gained access to the network.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: On April 14, 2016 (approximately three days after the initial intrusion) GRU officers downloaded rar.exe  onto the DCCC’s document server.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
The following day, the GRU searched one compromised DCCC computer for files containing search terms that included “Hillary,” “DNC,” “Cruz,” and “Trump.” 
April 28, 2016:
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The DNC contractor discovered unusual activity on the DNC network.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: “…the first day that we found activity on our network that was unusual, nefarious by adversaries…”  “we saw sort of very loud activity… on one of our Window servers that couldn’t have been done by one of us…an authorized user.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The kinds of activity we were looking at was accessing multiple different password vaults of different users, which is not something that anyone would do.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
And so that triggered an alarm for us…”  (p24)
April 30, 2016:
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike was contacted by the DNC outside counsel to discuss a suspected breach.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This was CrowdStrike’s first involvement in this matter.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html
Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: May 1-2, 2016:  CrowdStrike initiated an investigation into the breach of the DNC network.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html
Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The DNC network remediation took place.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html
Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike and the DNC outside counsel alerted the FBI that they had identified Russian actors on the DNC network.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html
Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The FBI requested forensic information, indicators of compromise (pieces of malicious code) that CrowdStrike discovered on the DNC computer network.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: With DNC permission, CrowdStrike continued to share information from the breach through December 2016, including “digital images” or copies of hard-drives.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html
Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The DNC, via CrowdStrike, publicly announced the breach of the DNC network and detailed its investigation.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html
Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The DCCC publicly announced it was a victim of Russian hacking.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: August 26, 2016:  Separate cyber activity continued on state election systems through Dec 29, 2016 ( p25-26.)
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Later it was discovered the Russians had, at least, scanned a total of 21 state election infrastructures.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
(p50)
September 20, 2016:
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: “On September 20, 2016, the GRU began to generate copies of the DNC data using [redacted] function designed to allow users to produce backups of databases (referred to [redacted] as “snapshots”).
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The GRU then stole those snapshots by moving them to
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: [redacted] account that they controlled, from there the copies were moved to GRU-controlled computers.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The GRU stole approximately 300 gigabytes of data from the DNC cloud-based account.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
(pp 49-50)
October 7, 2016:  DHS & ODNI release joint statement about stolen emails:  “The U.S. Intelligence Community (USIC) is confident that the Russian Government directed the recent compromises of e-mails from US persons and institutions, including from US political organizations….These thefts and disclosures are intended to interfere with the US election process.(p1)
January 6, 2017.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: “The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) designated the infrastructure used to administer the Nation’s elections as critical infrastructure.

 January 22, 2020 UPDATE
CrowdStrike is non-partisan – we routinely work with both Republican and Democratic organizations to protect them from cyber-attacks – along with thousands of other organizations around the world of all industries and sizes.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
Here are a few key facts about CrowdStrike:

We were founded in California and are headquartered in the heart of Silicon Valley in Sunnyvale, California.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We are one of the fastest growing global companies in cybersecurity today.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Our founders have no connections to Ukraine.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Suggestions to the contrary are completely false.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We have never had physical possession of the DNC servers.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We conducted our investigation using a process called “imaging” — an established practice in cyber investigations that involves making a copy of the hard drives and memory.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This is standard procedure for cyber investigations.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We worked closely with law enforcement and provided all forensic evidence and analysis to the FBI as requested.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We are proud of our work and will remain focused on our mission of protecting our customers around the world from dangerous cyber threats.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:

source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The New York Times, Republican-Led Review Backs Intelligence Findings on Russian Interference:
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: A three-year review by the Republican-led Senate Intelligence Committee unanimously found that the intelligence community assessment stating that Russia breached the DNC was fundamentally sound and untainted by politics.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

September 25, 2019 Update:
With regards to our investigation of the DNC hack in 2016, we provided all forensic evidence and analysis to the FBI.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: As we’ve stated before, we stand by our findings and conclusions that have been fully supported by the US Intelligence community.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
FAQ on Recent News Coverage of CrowdStrike
Is your owner Ukrainian?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: No.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike was founded by George Kurtz and Dmitri Alperovitch.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: George is an American entrepreneur and recognized security expert, author, entrepreneur, and speaker.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: He also started Foundstone, a worldwide security products and services company that was acquired by McAfee in 2004.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike’s Co-founder Dmitri Alperovitch is a Russia-born U.S. citizen, who has spent all of his adult life in the United States, and has no connection to Ukraine.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: As a public company, our ownership is available on the SEC.gov website.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Do you stand behind your work for the DNC?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: As we’ve repeatedly stated, we stand by the findings and analysis of our investigation, and, as detailed in our company statement, we’ve provided all forensic evidence and analysis to the FBI as requested.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Additionally, our findings have been supported by the U.S. intelligence community and other cybersecurity companies.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The investigation is detailed on our blog below.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Did you comply with FBI’s requests for information?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We’ve provided all forensic evidence and analysis to the FBI related to the DNC investigation as requested.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We have never declined any request for information from the FBI related to this investigation, and there are no pending requests for information by the FBI.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Do you have the DNC servers?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We have never taken physical possession of any DNC servers.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: When cyber investigators respond to an incident, they capture that evidence in a process called “imaging.”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: It involves making an exact byte-for-byte copy of the hard drives.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: They do the same for the machine’s memory, capturing evidence that would otherwise be lost at the next reboot, and they monitor and store the traffic passing through the victim’s network.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This has been standard procedure in incident response investigations for decades.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The images, not the computer’s hardware, provide the evidence.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Our cloud-native, crowdsourced approach to solving cybersecurity enables us to deliver state- of-the-art protection to organizations big and small.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Consequently, we are proud that customers from every major industry, level of government, and political affiliation turn to CrowdStrike to stop breaches.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Are you affiliated with the Democratic party?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike is not affiliated with any political party.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We are a public cybersecurity company, and are non-partisan.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We have done cybersecurity work for, and currently protect, both Republican and Democratic political organizations at the state, local, and federal level, and we have thousands of non-political companies and organizations as customers.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Do you have Secretary Hillary Clinton’s email server?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Have you ever had access to her emails?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: No.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We have never worked for Secretary Clinton or her campaign, and never had access to her server or emails.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Where can I find more information?
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Many news outlets have written about CrowdStrike’s investigation of the DNC hack and subsequent comments made by President Trump.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

June 15, 2016 UPDATE:
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike stands fully by its analysis and findings identifying two separate Russian intelligence-affiliated adversaries present in the DNC network in May 2016.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: On June 15, 2016 a blog post to a WordPress site authored by an individual using the moniker Guccifer 2.0 claimed credit for breaching the Democratic National Committee.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This blog post presents documents alleged to have originated from the DNC.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Whether or not this posting is part of a Russian Intelligence disinformation campaign, we are exploring the documents’ authenticity and origin.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Regardless, these claims do nothing to lessen our findings relating to the Russian government’s involvement, portions of which we have documented for the public and the greater security community.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
June 14, 2016
Bears in the Midst: Intrusion Into the Democratic National Committee
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
By Dmitri Alperovitch
There is rarely a dull day at CrowdStrike where we are not detecting or responding to a breach at a company somewhere around the globe.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: In all of these cases, we operate under strict confidentiality rules with our customers and cannot reveal publicly any information about these attacks.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: But on rare occasions, a customer decides to go public with information about their incident and give us permission to share our knowledge of the adversary tradecraft with the broader community and help protect even those who do not happen to be our customers.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This story is about one of those cases.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: CrowdStrike Services Inc., our Incident Response group, was called by the Democratic National Committee (DNC), the formal governing body for the US Democratic Party, to respond to a suspected breach.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We deployed our IR team and technology and immediately identified two sophisticated adversaries on the network – COZY BEAR and FANCY BEAR.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We’ve had lots of experience with both of these actors attempting to target our customers in the past and know them well.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: In fact, our team considers them some of the best threat actors out of all the numerous nation-state, criminal and hacktivist/terrorist groups we encounter on a daily basis.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Their tradecraft is superb, operational security second to none and the extensive usage of ‘living-off-the-land’ techniques enables them to easily bypass many security solutions they encounter.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: In particular, we identified advanced methods consistent with nation-state level capabilities including deliberate targeting and ‘access management’ tradecraft – both groups were constantly going back into the environment to change out their implants, modify persistent methods, move to new Command & Control channels and perform other tasks to try to stay ahead of being detected.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Both adversaries engage in extensive political and economic espionage for the benefit of the government of the Russian Federation and are believed to be closely linked to the Russian government’s powerful and highly capable intelligence services.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: COZY BEAR (also referred to in some industry reports as CozyDuke or APT 29) is the adversary group that last year successfully infiltrated the unclassified networks of the White House, State Department, and US Joint Chiefs of Staff.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: In addition to the US government, they have targeted organizations across the Defense, Energy, Extractive, Financial, Insurance, Legal, Manufacturing Media, Think Tanks, Pharmaceutical, Research and Technology industries, along with Universities.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Victims have also been observed in Western Europe, Brazil, China, Japan, Mexico, New Zealand, South Korea, Turkey and Central Asian countries.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: COZY BEAR’s preferred intrusion method is a broadly targeted spearphish campaign that typically includes web links to a malicious dropper.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Once executed on the machine, the code will deliver one of a number of sophisticated Remote Access Tools (RATs), including AdobeARM, ATI-Agent, and MiniDionis.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: On many occasions, both the dropper and the payload will contain a range of techniques to ensure the sample is not being analyzed on a virtual machine, using a debugger, or located within a sandbox.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: They have extensive checks for the various security software that is installed on the system and their specific configurations.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: When specific versions are discovered that may cause issues for the RAT, it promptly exits.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: These actions demonstrate a well-resourced adversary with a thorough implant-testing regime that is highly attuned to slight configuration issues that may result in their detection, and which would cause them to deploy a different tool instead.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The implants are highly configurable via encrypted configuration files, which allow the adversary to customize various components, including C2 servers, the list of initial tasks to carry out, persistence mechanisms, encryption keys and others.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: An HTTP protocol with encrypted payload is used for the Command & Control communication.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: FANCY BEAR (also known as Sofacy or APT 28) is a separate Russian-based threat actor, which has been active since mid 2000s, and has been responsible for targeted intrusion campaigns against the Aerospace, Defense, Energy, Government and Media sectors.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Their victims have been identified in the United States, Western Europe, Brazil, Canada, China, Georgia, Iran, Japan, Malaysia and South Korea.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Extensive targeting of defense ministries and other military victims has been observed, the profile of which closely mirrors the strategic interests of the Russian government, and may indicate affiliation with Главное Разведывательное Управление (Main Intelligence Department) or GRU, Russia’s premier military intelligence service.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This adversary has a wide range of implants at their disposal, which have been developed over the course of many years and include Sofacy, X-Agent, X-Tunnel, WinIDS, Foozer and DownRage droppers, and even malware for Linux, OSX, IOS, Android and Windows Phones.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: This group is known for its technique of registering domains that closely resemble domains of legitimate organizations they plan to target.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Afterwards, they establish phishing sites on these domains that spoof the look and feel of the victim’s web-based email services in order to steal their credentials.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: FANCY BEAR has also been linked publicly to intrusions into the German Bundestag and France’s TV5 Monde TV station in April 2015.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: At DNC, COZY BEAR intrusion has been identified going back to summer of 2015, while FANCY BEAR separately breached the network in April 2016.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: We have identified no collaboration between the two actors, or even an awareness of one by the other.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Instead, we observed the two Russian espionage groups compromise the same systems and engage separately in the theft of identical credentials.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: While you would virtually never see Western intelligence agencies going after the same target without de-confliction for fear of compromising each other’s operations, in Russia this is not an uncommon scenario.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: “Putin’s Hydra: Inside Russia’s Intelligence Services”, a recent paper from European Council on Foreign Relations, does an excellent job outlining the highly adversarial relationship between Russia’s main intelligence services – Федеральная Служба Безопасности (FSB), the primary domestic intelligence agency but one with also significant external collection and ‘active measures’  remit, Служба Внешней Разведки (SVR), the primary foreign intelligence agency, and the aforementioned GRU.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Not only do they have overlapping areas of responsibility, but also rarely share intelligence and even occasionally steal sources from each other and compromise operations.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Thus, it is not surprising to see them engage in intrusions against the same victim, even when it may be a waste of resources and lead to the discovery and potential compromise of mutual operations.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The COZY BEAR intrusion relied primarily on the SeaDaddy implant developed in Python and compiled with py2exe and another Powershell backdoor with persistence accomplished via Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) system, which allowed the adversary to launch malicious code automatically after a specified period of system uptime or on a specific schedule.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The Powershell backdoor is ingenious in its simplicity and power.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
It consists of a single obfuscated command setup to run persistently, such as:
powershell.exe -NonInteractive
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

sWP ‘Wmi’ ‘Wmi’ $aeK $aeI | Out-Null

This one-line powershell command, stored only in WMI database, establishes an encrypted connection to C2 and downloads additional powershell modules from it, executing them in memory.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: In theory, the additional modules can do virtually anything on the victim system.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The encryption keys in the script were different on every system.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Powershell version of credential theft tool MimiKatz was also used by the actors to facilitate credential acquisition for lateral movement purposes.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: FANCY BEAR adversary used different tradecraft, deploying X-Agent malware with capabilities to do remote command execution, file transmission and keylogging.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text:
It was executed via rundll32 commands such as:
rundll32.exe “C:\Windows\twain_64.dll”
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: In addition, FANCY BEAR’s X-Tunnel network tunneling tool, which facilitates connections to NAT-ed environments, was used to also execute remote commands.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Both tools were deployed via RemCOM, an open-source replacement for PsExec available from GitHub.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: They also engaged in a number of anti-forensic analysis measures, such as periodic event log clearing (via wevtutil cl System  and wevtutil cl Security  commands) and resetting timestamps of files.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Intelligence collection directed by nation state actors against US political targets provides invaluable insight into the requirements directed upon those actors.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Regardless of the agency or unit tasked with this collection, the upcoming US election, and the associated candidates and parties are of critical interest to both hostile and friendly nation states.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: The 2016 presidential election has the world’s attention, and leaders of other states are anxiously watching and planning for possible outcomes.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

text: Attacks against electoral candidates and the parties they represent are likely to continue up until the election in November.
source: Our Work with the DNC_ Setting the record straight.html

SOCIAL ENGINEERING
Less technically challenging CosmicDuke samples use
simple social engineering to trick the user into willingly
launching the attack file.

Once launched, the file drops
the malware onto the system (such files are therefore
referred to as droppers in the rest of this documents).

To do so, the malware’s executable file is first disguised as
an image or document to make it seem innocuous.

When
launched, a document or image is displayed in order to
draw the user’s attention away from any background
activity.

In the meantime, the malware’s malicious files are
silently installed and executed on the system.

The sample makes HTTP GET requests to the server(s)

The GET request contains

y m or mgn

y Session

y FamilyID
y BranchID

y User

The first field, m or mgn, does not have any value.
The value of Auth is the ID of the sample.

It is the same
8-character hex digit that can be found in the PDB path,
among other places.
The value of Query depends on the request.

It is either
encoded using URL safe base64, or then the value is
a 1792-character string.

256-character string that is repeated seven times.

Unit 42 Technical Analysis: Seaduke


51,915
 people reacted

4
  6  min. read



Share 


















 







          By Josh Grunzweig 
July 14, 2015 at 9:47 AM
Category: Malware, Threat Prevention, Unit 42
Tags: Duke malware, forkmeiamfamous, Seaduke, Symantec, Trojan



 


Earlier this week Symantec released a blog post detailing a new Trojan used by the ‘Duke’ family of malware.
Within this blog post, a payload containing a function named ‘forkmeiamfamous’ was mentioned.
While performing some research online, Unit 42 was able to identify the following sample, which is being labeled as ‘Trojan.Win32.Seadask’ by a number of anti-virus companies.

MD5
A25EC7749B2DE12C2A86167AFA88A4DD


SHA1
BB71254FBD41855E8E70F05231CE77FEE6F00388


SHA256
3EB86B7B067C296EF53E4857A74E09F12C2B84B666FC130D1F58AEC18BC74B0D


Compile Timestamp
2013-03-23 22:26:55


File type
PE32 executable (GUI) Intel 80386, for MS Windows, UPX compressed



Our analysis has turned up more technical details and indicators on the malware itself that aren’t mentioned in Symantec’s post.

Here are some of our observations:
First Layer of Obfuscation
Once the UPX packer is removed from the malware sample, it becomes quickly apparent that we’re dealing with a sample compiled using PyInstaller.
This program allows an individual to write a program using the Python scripting language and convert it into an executable for the Microsoft Windows, Linux, Mac OSX, Solaris, or AIX platform.
The following subset of strings that were found within the UPX-unpacked binary confirms our suspicions.

sys.path.append(r"%s")
del sys.path[:]
import sys
PYTHONHOME
PYTHONPATH
Error in command: %s
sys.path.append(r"%s?%d")
_MEI%d
INTERNAL ERROR: cannot create temporary directory!

WARNING: file already exists but should not: %s
Error creating child process!

Cannot GetProcAddress for PySys_SetObject
PySys_SetObject

Because the sample was written in Python originally, we’re able to extract the underlying code.

A tool such as ‘PyInstaller Extractor’ can be used to extract the underlying pyc files present within the binary.

Figure 1.

Extracted Python files from Seaduke
We can then use a tool such as uncompyle2 to convert the Python byte-code into the original source code.
Once this process is completed, we quickly realize that the underlying Python code has been obfuscated.

Figure 2. Obfuscated Python code
Second Layer of Obfuscation
Tracing through the obfuscated code, we identify an ‘exec(ZxkBDKLakV)’ statement, which will presumably execute some Python code.
Tracing further, we discover that this string is generated via appending a number of strings to the ‘ZxkBDKLakV’ variable.
Finally, we find that after this string is created, it is base64-decoded and subsequently decompressed using the ZLIB library.
Figure 3.

Second layer of obfuscation identified
The following simple Python code can be used to circumvent this layer of obfuscation:

The remaining Python code still appears to be obfuscated, however, overall functionality can be identified.

Final Payload
As we can see below, almost all variable names and class names have been obfuscated using long unique strings.
Figure 4.

Obfuscation discovered in final payload
Using a little brainpower and search/replace, we can begin identifying and renaming functionality within the malware.
A cleaned up copy of this code can be found on GitHub.
One of the first things we notice is a large blob of base64-encoded data, which is additionally decompressed using ZLIB.
Once we decode and decompress this data, we are rewarded with a JSON object containing configuration data for this malware:
After this data is identified, we begin tracing execution of the malware from the beginning.
When the malware is initially run, it will determine on which operating system it is running.
Should it be running on a non-Windows system, we see a call to the infamous ‘forkmeiamfamous’ method.
This method is responsible for configuring a number of Unix-specific settings, and forking the process.
Figure 6.

Main execution of malware
Continuing along, we discover that this malware has the ability to persist using one of the following techniques:

Persistence via PowerShell
Persistence via the Run registry key
Persistence via a .lnk file stored in the Startup directory
The malware copies itself to a file name referenced in the JSON configuration.

Figure 7. Persistence techniques
After the malware installs itself, it begins making network requests.
All network communications are performed over HTTP for this particular sample; however, it appears to support HTTPS as well.
When the malware makes the initial outbound connection, a specific Cookie value is used.
Figure 8.

Initial HTTP request made
In actuality, this Cookie value contains encrypted data.
The base64-encoded data is parsed from the Cookie value (padding is added as necessary).
EBJhZTlKiqN8nYWejKh7UpDycPlcrGMEcTE=
The resulting decoded data is shown below.

\x10\x12ae9J\x8a\xa3|\x9d\x85\x9e\x8c\xa8{R\x90\xf2p\xf9\\\xacc\x04q1
The underlying data has the following characteristics.

Figure 9. Cookie data structure
XORing the first single character against the second character identifies the length of the random string.
Using the above example, we get the following.

First Character  : '\x10'
Second Character : '\x12'
String Length (16 ^ 18) : 2
Random String    : 'ae'
Encrypted Data   : '9J\x8a\xa3|\x9d\x85\x9e\x8c\xa8{R\x90\xf2p\xf9\\\xacc\x04q1'
Finally, the encrypted data is encrypted using the RC4 algorithm.
The key is generated by concatenating the previously used random string with the new one, and taking the SHA1 hash of this data.
This same key is used to decrypt any response data provided by the server.
The server attempts to mimic a HTML page and provides base64-encoded data within the response, as shown below.
Figure 10.

Server response
Data found within tags in the HTML response is joined together and the white space is removed.
This data is then base64-decoded with additional characters (‘-_’)
prior to being decrypted via RC4 using the previously discussed key.
After decryption occurs, the previous random string used in key generation is updated with the random string.
In doing so, the attackers have ensured that no individual HTTP session can be decrypted without seeing the previous session.
If the decrypted data does not produce proper JSON data, Seaduke will discard it and enter a sleep cycle.
Otherwise, this JSON data will be parsed for commands.
The following commands have been identified in Seaduke.

Command
Description


cd
Change working directory to one specified


pwd
Return present working directory


cdt
Change working directory to %TEMP%


autoload
Install malware in specified location


migrate
Migrate processes


clone_time
Clone file timestamp information


download
Download file


execw
Execute command


get
Get information about a file


upload
Upload file to specified URL


b64encode
Base64-encode file data and return result


eval
Execute Python code


set_update_interval
Update sleep timer between main network requests


self_exit
Terminate malware


seppuku
Terminate and uninstall malware
In order for the ‘self_exit’ or ‘seppuku’ commands to properly execute, the attackers must supply a secondary argument of ‘YESIAMSURE’.

Conclusion
Overall, Seaduke is quite sophisticated.
While written in Python, the malware employs a number of interesting techniques for encrypting data over the network and persisting on the victim machine.
WildFire customers are protected against this threat.
Additionally, Palo Alto Networks properly categorizes the URL used by Seaduke as malicious.
